description.narrative: Insatsens övergripande mål är att (i)öka motståndskraften vad gäller klimatförändringar bland småbrukare i torra och halvtorra områden; (ii) förbättra deras hantering av vattenresurser och lokala avrinningsområden, samt; (iii) åstadkomma ett ökat och hållbart utbyte för dessa småbrukare från deras lantbruksbaserade prouktion.

The overall objectives are to (i) increase resilience to climate risks among small scale farmers living in arid and semi-arid areas; (ii) improve their manegement of water resources and local watersheds, and; (iii) generate increased and sustainable returns from their agricultural production.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2014Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The Embassy assess that the intended outcome has been reached since it has contributed to improving the living conditions among small farmers in arid and semi-arid areas in Bolivia that are climatically vulnerable and where even small climate change increases vulnerability. A mid-term review commissioned by Sida in 2013 as well as a CAP (Control de Avance de Programa) which in the GIZ process is the combined results evaluation of PROAGRO 2 and planning for the next phase, were carried out during 2013. The mid-term review of PROAGRO 2 commissioned by the Embassy concluded that the program has led to more than expected results and in less time than planned. The results were corroborated with field visits, on average two per year. The following achievements can be mentioned: 18,905 families are applying three out of the 9 management models developed to increase the water efficiency use for agricultural production (water harvesting, conventional furrow irrigation and mechanized irrigation) which is more target families than planned. Data showed that families who are able to irrigate as little as 15,000 sq. metres, were able to overcome poverty sustainably and increase livelihood resilience because they were able to diversify their production, harvest twice per year and could plan production to coincide with the best market prices. The project enabled 31,707 small scale farmer families to increase their farm income with between 50% and 650% depending on the management models they were applying. Those farmers applying three out of nine management models (water harvesting, conventional furrow irrigation and mechanized irrigation) were able to increase incomes with up to 300% and those farmers in the dry Chaco area who used the models with improved pastures and feed for their livestock earned up to 650% more. Four models of water management are supported and extended by 18 partner organisations within Integrated Water Resource Management (IWRM) aiming at reaching a higher level of accessible water in the river basins through a combination of protection of water sources, reduced sedimentation, water harvesting and water conservation agreements. Thanks to the new irrigation systems the benefitted families can expand and diversify their agriculture to include vegetables and other commercial crops. Different management models for production and commercialisation are implemented by 18 partner organisations in the area. This enables the municipalities to seek financial and technical support from different sources and they can develop commercial ventures which benefit the community. For example, there are municipalities that have been able to develop the production of apples. There is a small national market in Bolivia with good price despite competition from the big regional producers. Associations of fruit producers have been started, and they have built commercial collection centres, in order to make the production more efficient with possibilities to sort, qualify and package the produce. Besides boosting the income the production has helped the families to secure food supply which especially benefits children. The national agricultural development institute INIAF, has developed drought tolerant varieties of maize that give more reliable harvests in times of climate change.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
